title: Ask HN: Do we still value Aaron Swartz in a modern psychiatric paradigm
text:
In the modern psychiatric paradigm, Aaron Swartz is easily dismissable as bipolar. As a Dasein whos internal reality we are not doomed to respect, as fellow Daseines--he is "other".

Do we owe anything to those that we believe to be right, under these other-labeling paradigms?

Tell HN: AWS does not require email confirmation for email or password changes
text:
Hey everyone,

I created a new AWS account over the weekend for a hobby project. Tonight I got an email that my password and email had both been changed. I hadn't set up MFA yet simply because I hadn't even used the account yet.

I'm just shocked that Amazon doesn't even send a "Hey we're about to lock you out, is this okay?" email before allowing someone to completely take over.

As for the compromise, waiting to hear back on how this happened. I confirmed the password I used isn't in haveibeenpwned. A keylogger seems unlikely since none of my other sensitive accounts have had issues. Just in utter disbelief that account changes would be allowed without any confirmation.

Ask HN: Learning Networks?
text:
I’ve always been fascinated by networking and want to see if there is an angle I can shift my career into.

I’ve done networking on AWS, VPCs, subnets, AWS cert type stuff. Recently I’ve been automating my homelab and having fun with iptables and Docker networks. I’ve played a little bit with some low level TCP handshake stuff, but curious where I go from here? I was reading this dense 1000 page networking book a bit in the beginning to more deeply understand the math for CIDR blocks and IP addressing, but it was a lot to tackle for a beginner networking nerd.

FWIW I’m a senior SWE at big tech company, but these days, you don’t do much low level packet stuff!

Ask HN: Best SaaS sign up flow? (first company)
text:
I'm working on a software to help companies be more productive.

The current registration flow consists of two approaches-

1. People can simply email/contact us and we can create an account for them.

2. Register on the website (gonna launch it soon for broader audience). You enter your name, company name, email and password, and you're sent an email with a link to verify your email address. You click it, and you can log in.

Once the first company user is set up, they can then go ahead and add their company details, invite their employees, set up SSO, create roles and do whatever customizations/admin stuff.

My question - what's the best SaaS sign up flow? How does each flow fit with the type of customer I'm trying to go after? For example, do different types/size of companies care about the sign up flow?

I've used tools before where I enter some information, and I'm immediately logged into the application and I'm ready to start. Some send a code to email that needs to be entered.

I've used others where the flow is similar to ours with a simple email verification link.

title: GPT3/DallE in Discord (updates), permanent memory done, auto-moderation, more
text:
A few weeks ago I posted a project over at https://github.com/Kav-K/GPT3Discord, which was a discord bot that effectively integrates GPT3 and DALL-E right into Discord, with a ton of quality of life features and functionalities that I didn't find present in other things online.

I mentioned earlier that I was working on implementing permanent memory using embeddings, and that work is done and ready for alpha!

Some new cool stuff (you can see the main list of features on the README or in my original post):

- Permanent memory using embeddings, you can chat more accurately, for longer, and preserve tokens better with this

- AI-based Automatic server moderation was also added

- Group chats with GPT3

- Better image prompt optimizer, now works exceptionally well for Midjourney and Stable Diffusion too!

- Entirely revamped for discord slash commands, reliability, and performance in high-throughput environments

Ask HN: Dice Unsearchable Profile
text:
Dice.com has made my profile unsearchable, yet they don't provide any clear explanation for the offending issue. I obviously deny their claims. Has anyone experienced this issue and is there any way to resolve it?

*Your account will remain unsearchable in our system until the profile and resume have been completed following all Terms of Services agreed to upon registration.

This profile was identified as having misrepresented information. This could include but is not limited to the accuracy of physical residing location, visa status, valid full first and last name, work authorization, representation, deletion of multiple profiles, or a Terms of Service violation.

Ensure to remove contact information and social links from resume for security feature purposes.*

Show HN: I asked ChatGPT to convert a Chrome ext to a Firefox ext
text:
I told it to create a virtual machine first:

  I want you to act as a Linux terminal. I will type commands and you will reply with what the terminal should show. I want you to only reply with the terminal output inside one unique code block, and nothing else. Do no write explanations. Do not type commands unless I instruct you to do so. When I need to tell you something in English I will do so by putting text inside curly brackets {like this}. My first command is pwd.
Then I told it to create a python script to do the conversion:

  {Create and write to the filesystem a python script called convert.py that takes a URL as its first argument. The URL is a chrome extension. The script then converts the extension to a Firefox extension and saves the result in a directory called "res". Make sure the script works with an actual URL to a chrome extension on the Chrome Webstore. It requires you to possibly download the extension first from the URL. Also make sure the generated Firefox extension meets all the requirements and the Chrome to Firefox conversion takes place for all assets in the extension, it includes the content scripts, etc. Only print done to the terminal here when finished.}
Then ran it with this URL (URL to Google Translate Chrome ext):

  python convert.py "https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/google-translate/aapbdbdomjkkjkaonfhkkikfgjllcleb?hl=en&gl=BG&authuser=1"
It actually created a zipped Firefox extension with the manifest file converted correctly, etc.
